document.heading: Restoring Trust and Credibility to Forensic Sciences Amendment Act of 2022

To amend the Department of Forensic Sciences Establishment Act of 2011 to redesignate the Department of Forensic Sciences as the Forensic Sciences and Public Health Laboratory, to redesignate the Forensic Sciences and Public Health Laboratory as an independent agency within the executive branch of the District of Columbia government, to amend the qualifications and term of the Director, to expand the types of documents that are to be made publicly available, to amend the duties of the Director, to codify the budget process for the Forensic Sciences and Public Health Laboratory, to establish the position of Chief Forensic Sciences Officer within the Forensic Sciences and Public Health Laboratory, to address circumstances that unduly bias the provision of forensic sciences services and independence of the Forensic Sciences and Public Health Laboratory, to redesignate the Science Advisory Board as the Science Advisory and Review Board, to provide for a robust procedure for addressing self-disclosures, complaints, or allegations of testing errors before the Science Advisory and Review Board, to require that correspondence and reports published by the Science Advisory and Review Board be made public, to expand membership and change the qualifications for members on the Science Advisory and Review Board, and to grant access to the Science Advisory and Review Board to all records of the Forensic Sciences and Public Health Laboratory; and to make other technical and conforming changes.

history.summary: BILL SUMMARY - As introduced Bill 24-838 would incorporate recommendations of SNA International, Inc. as well as additional reforms to the Department of Forensic Sciences to fulfill its mission of providing timely, accurate, and reliable forensic science and public health laboratory services.

document.text: BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be cited as the "Restoring Trust and Credibility to Forensic Sciences Amendment Act of 2022".

section.heading: Director; appointment, qualifications, compensation, and term.

para.text: The Laboratory shall be headed by a Director who shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Council.

The Mayor shall submit a nomination for the position of Director to the Council for a 90-day period of review, excluding days of Council recess. If the Council does not approve or disapprove the nomination, by resolution, within the 90-day review period, the nomination shall be deemed disapproved.
The Director shall have demonstrated knowledge of forensic sciences and have:
Graduated from an accredited college or university with a master's degree or higher in an applicable area of science;
Demonstrated management and administrative skills in the public or private sector; and
A minimum of 5 years' management-level experience supervising employees in a government agency or private business association with more than 50 employees.

The Director shall be compensated at a rate equal to Level 3 of the Public Safety Executive Service pay schedule pursuant to section 1052a of the District of Columbia Government Comprehensive Merit Personnel Act of 1978, effective May 2, 2015 (D.C. Law 20-267; D.C. Official Code § 1-610.52a).
The Director shall be appointed for a 6-year term.

If a vacancy in the position of Director occurs as a consequence of resignation, disability, death, or reason other than the expiration of the term of the Director, the Mayor shall appoint a replacement, subject to confirmation by the Council, to fill the unexpired term. A person appointed to fill the unexpired term shall serve only for the remainder of the term.
The Director shall not be subject to removal from office before expiration of the Director's term, except upon a written finding of the Mayor of good cause, subject to the right of appeal.
No person shall serve as Director in a holdover capacity for longer than 180 days after the expiration of the term.

section.heading: Chief Forensic Sciences Officer; appointment, qualifications, duties, and other personnel.

para.text: The Mayor shall appoint, with the advice and consent of the Council in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection, a Chief Forensic Sciences Officer of the Laboratory. The Chief Forensic Sciences Officer shall report directly to the Director and may be removed only by the Mayor upon a written finding of good cause, subject to the right of appeal.

The Mayor shall submit a nomination for Chief Forensic Sciences Officer to the Council for a 90-day period of review, excluding days of Council recess. If the Council does not approve or disapprove the nomination, by resolution, within the 90-day review period, the nomination shall be deemed disapproved.
To be eligible for appointment, the Chief Forensic Sciences Officer shall have:
Graduated from an accredited college or university with a masters or doctoral degree in an applicable area of science or forensic analysis;
Demonstrated training and experience in scientific research and methodology;
Demonstrated management and administrative experience;
Demonstrated comprehensive knowledge of forensic sciences;
A minimum of 10 years' experience being employed at a forensic sciences laboratory; and
A minimum of 5 years' experience directing or supervising both scientific and administrative staff in a forensic science laboratory setting.
The Chief Forensic Sciences Officer shall:
Oversee the operations of all forensic science services in the Laboratory;
Ensure that all forensic science services in the Laboratory are in compliance with accreditation requirements and meet rigorous evidence-based practices;
Ensure that accreditation and evidence-based practices for all forensic science services in the Laboratory are maintained;
Address and rectify nonconformances for all forensic science services in the Laboratory;
Develop and promulgate training manuals and standard operating procedures, including:
Protocols for forensic testing, examination, and analysis;
Procedures for handling case-specific information to minimize bias;
Standards for the maintenance and calibration of all equipment and materials, including standards for maintaining logs documenting the maintenance and calibration performed;
Procedures for estimations of uncertainty;
Procedures for monitoring the quality of forensic analysis;
Procedures for regular internal and external audits;
Proficiency testing protocols;
Internal validation studies; and
Standards for reporting results, including model laboratory reports and guidelines for the presentation of results in court; and
Address and implement any corrective action identified by the Board pursuant to section 13a(c)(1)(C).

section.heading: Process for addressing allegations of negligence, misconduct, misidentification, or other testing errors.

para.text: A self-disclosure, complaint, or allegation concerning professional negligence, misconduct, misidentification, or other testing errors that occurs in the provision of forensic science services or public health laboratory services shall be investigated by the Laboratory.

If the Laboratory receives a self-disclosure, complaint, or becomes aware of an allegation concerning professional negligence, misconduct, misidentification, or other testing errors that occurs in the provision of forensic science services or public health laboratory services, the complaint or allegation shall be:
Reported to the Board within 24 business hours after it is received by the Laboratory; and
Acknowledged by the Laboratory to the complainant within 2 business days of receipt.

Upon completion of the investigation by the Laboratory into the self-disclosure, complaint, or allegation, within 2 business days, the Laboratory shall provide all relevant documents, including findings and recommended corrective actions, to the Board.
Upon receipt of the documents used by the Laboratory in its investigation into the self-disclosure, complaint, or allegation, the Board shall determine whether the complaint or allegation merits:
An investigation by the Board;
A review of the self-disclosure, complaint, or allegation for educational purposes;
Additional review by the Laboratory into the self-disclosure, complaint, or allegation; or
No further review.
The Board shall communicate its decision in writing within 10 business days after receipt to the complainant and the Director.

The Board may reconsider its disposition of a self-disclosure, complaint, or allegation if new evidence of negligence, misconduct, misidentification, or other testing errors is presented to the Board.
If the Board conducts an investigation or review pursuant to subsection (b)(2)(A) or (B) of this section, the Board:
Shall prepare a written report that identifies and describes:
The methods or procedures used to identify the self-disclosure or alleged negligence, misconduct, misidentification, or other testing errors;
Whether any negligence, misconduct, misidentification, or other testing errors occurred;
Any corrective action required of the Laboratory;
Observations of the Board regarding the integrity and reliability of the forensic science services or public health laboratory services conducted;
Best practices identified by the Board during the investigation or review; and
Other recommendations that are relevant, as determined by the Board; and
May order:

A retrospective reexamination of other forensic science services or public health laboratory services conducted by the Laboratory that may involve professional negligence, misconduct, misidentification, or other testing errors; or
An evaluation of the Laboratory to review the implementation of any corrective action required or the conclusion of any retrospective reexamination.
The Board shall make all correspondence and reports completed under this section available to the public through the Laboratory's website.

para.text: This act shall apply upon the date of inclusion of its fiscal effect in an approved budget and financial plan.

The Chief Financial Officer shall certify the date of the inclusion of the fiscal effect in an approved budget and financial plan, and provide notice to the Budget Director of the Council for certification.
The Budget Director shall cause the notice of the certification to be published in the District of Columbia Register.
The date of publication of the notice of the certification shall not affect the applicability of this act.

section.heading: Fiscal impact statement.
section.text: The Council adopts the fiscal impact statement in the committee report as the fiscal impact statement required by section 4a of the General Legislative Procedures Act of 1975, approved October 16, 2006 (120 Stat. 2038; D.C. Official Code § 1-301.47a).

section.heading: Effective date.
section.text: This act shall take effect following approval by the Mayor (or in the event of veto by the Mayor, action by the Council to override the veto), a 60-day period of congressional review as provided in section 602(c)(2) of the District of Columbia Home Rule Act, approved December 24, 1973 (87 Stat. 813; D.C. Official Code § 1-206.02(c)(2)), and publication in the District of Columbia Register.
